pros: Hahnemann provides a lot of education, and offers incentives to continue one's education and  pursue advanced degrees.  Due to the hospital's location, one gains experience with a diverse patient population.  The compensation seems reasonable; neither the highest nor the lowest in the city.  There are often opportunities for overtime, which is important to RNs.  Hahnemann is part of Tenet Healthcare, the second largest healthcare organization in the U.S., so I would imagine if one was interested in relocating there would be opportunities to do so.
cons: This is my first job as an RN, so I'm not able to compare Hahnemann to other hospitals.  Hahnemann is certainly trying to run "lean," so being pulled or cancelled is not uncommon, but I would honestly expect this to be similar to other hospitals.  Sometimes, it feels like we might not have all the support, supplies, or equipment that we need to do the job optimally, but once again, I would guess RNs feel that way at other hospitals at times, too.  Personally, part of the attraction to me of being an RN is being a problem-solver -- being flexible, thinking creatively, and finding solutions -- rather than bemoaning a lack of support, and I think those attributes are a requirement of being an RN, not just at Hahnemann but anywhere.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Chennai
pros: Good corkers that we’re there
cons: Bad upper management that were there

pros: the hospital is now closed
cons: the management is poor. hospital is now closed

pros: I met some great coworkers here. Thats all
cons:
Alot. 
Management is the worse. They dont listen to their employee. They change policy according to their needs. 
Cannot take  vacation because they are always short staffed and you lose it upon leaving the job. So whats the point of having it.
Employees are forced to "flex" if they think they are not busy which is leaving work early or come late and using PTO for that. This way you wont have enough to go on vacation if you want , thats if they let you

Over a period of two years over 15 people left in one department and no one questioned the manager why. Proof of bad management 
Favoritism among employee, write up for new one and old employees get only an email to tell them oh watch out.
You will never get a recommendation from management for future job just because you decide to leave. 
They force you to work other shifts even if you cant. 
They force people to work 16 hours shift
The list is long. The point is to not work here and waste your time

pros: HUH hires new nurses... That's all I've got...
cons: No advancement what so ever, doesn't exist! Worst so-called management team I've ever worked with, lots of favoritism, everyone in management were buddies. Low staff morale due to low pay, horrible benefits, tough patients and work load, no appreciation from management. Dirty, filthy work conditions, high work load including tasks that were not included in job description. Nurses left before orientation was over, I was considered having high seniority after being there 18 months! No staff education provided... I almost left the field of nursing soon after starting here bc of the work conditions and such low pay and expensive benefits

pros: Hospital is easy to travel to and the parking is really inexpensive. The supervisors are great and friendly with a lot of years of experience. There are lab celebrations that bring everyone together. The employees are kind to each other in the lab and are appreciated by the managers.
cons: The nurses don't respect the lab and the lab is busy at times trying to resolve their issues. We are educated and work very hard at our position and would like to be acknowledged. The security isn't as tight as it could be with many people wondering around.  Patients are allowed to wonder around with their IV poles off the floors, in the cafeteria , outside and sometimes down to the 7 eleven.

pros: I was hired as a new grad nurse and they put a lot of time and effort into orienting and training me.  My starting salary was fair at $27.50/hr as an RN in 2013 and increased to $31.16/hr within the first year.  Staff is generally very friendly, fun, and morale seems high in my opinion.  I personally love the people I work with.  I find it to be a very supporting learning environment because it is a teaching hospital.  Mistakes are used a teaching opportunity and not an excuse to discipline. I feel it is a safe place to practice because patient to nurse ratio in my department is strictly 4:1. There are a lot of new grad nurses, residents, and younger attending physicians working here.  Location is awesome, right in the heart of Philly so you get a very diverse patient population. The hospital is very proud of its Magnet status and works hard to fulfill it's mission and requirement.  Cafeteria food is good and cheap!  Also there is great tuition reimbursement of 10k/year plus 30% discount off Drexel University tuition.  Overtime is sometimes available but staffing is often adequate for the patient census.
cons: Hahnemann can be a difficult place to work because of the patient population.  Lots of vagrants, drunks, drug addicts, seekers, homeless looking for a warm place to stay, and just generally rude/demanding people.  Many of these patients are low SES and completely reliant on "the system" to take care of them.   The scheduling policies are terrible in my department.  All staff hired after a certain date (long passed) have to rotate from days to nights based on the "needs" of the department.  Vacation time has to be requested months in advance in order to take a day off.  Hahnemann nurses have no union representing them. Health benefits are cheap ($15/pay period) but mediocre and force you to use Hahnemann for all your healthcare needs.  Staff turnover is high but people have a way of leaving and then coming back to Hahnemann once they've experienced what it's like to work elsewhere.

review_title: Coworkers are the only reason I've stayed
pros: Coworkers are great and everyone works together to make it through the shift, great way to learn time management, good first job for experience
cons: Management cuts every corner they can to save $$, nurses are either cancelled, pulled, or understaffed, RNs are given more and more responsibilities with less and less support, lots of young nurses and high turnover rate, terrible 'raises' per experience acquired, recently hired personal care associates are also understaffed and overworked, charge nurse has a full assignment on top of charge duties

pros: Great experience for a new nurse. The doctors are great.
cons: Sometimes it feels as though management does things just to cross it off a list, to get it done. There is a push for nurses to work themselves to death and then management is surprised by the resulting call outs and excessive nurse turn over.

pros: I have worked with this company for more than 6 years. There are some good perks employee discount. Insurance prices are reasonable.
cons: Micro-management. It feels like you are in Kinder Garten. There are so many newly graduates run this facility with no experience. Most people come to collect the pay check. Very few people actually likes to work.

review_title: Sounds like a great place, but it is NOT!!!
pros: The floor staff is friendly and team work can be found throughout most of the hospital
cons: The salary is below the national average, there is no praise for a job well done, the patients are all homeless, rude, outstay the medical need for them to be there, there is no incentive to do or be better,  there is no help i.e. nurses aids, iv teams, transport (at night) and very high patient ratio

review_title: Good first job out of nursing school. Get out after you get the experience to get into a better supported institution.
pros: Benefits are getting better. Staff are nice to each other in some departments. Education repayment and ability to seek higher degree's. Union protection, wages coming up.
cons: Horrible management. Lost a lot of specialties. Staffing cuts, re-assignments, and equipment hasn't been updated since the 80's

review_title: Private hospital, good staff, Tenet working to improve reputation
pros:
-Location
-Dedicated Staff
-Interesting pathology and patient population
-Forms part of largest medical school in the USA
cons:
-Competition from many adjacent healthcare systems
-Stringent emphasis on profit bottom line without due consideration of other factors
-Dicey history of owning company, however, to my knowledge this particular institution has not been involved in such activities

review_title: Good for experience but is a very stressful work environment
pros: You will learn a lot due to the varied patient population. Helps you to develop skills while working under pressure.
cons: Too many patients to each nurse. Management expects you to do too much in too little time and you will get in trouble if you stay late clocked in to finish up. Not enough support for nurses. Tough patient population.

pros: Co-workers and supervisor were great. Paid well. Regular hours when I started out as per diem. Promises kept. Good benefits.
cons: This hospital is DIRTY. The equipment does not work. Needed new equipment when I was hired, and never received any 2 years later when I left. Did not feel patients were safe here. The union is useless.

pros: Tuition reimbursement is excellent. 10,000/year which is unheard of in surrounding hospitals. I have gained a lot of experience and have felt like I can handle most critical medical situations due to working in such a high stress environment. 401k and health insurance comparable to other hospitals in the area. Nurses and residents make great teams especially in the ICUs. Most attending are nice and want nurses to feel involved in patient rounds in ICUs.
cons: Literally the worst hospital I have ever worked at. Management absolutely does not care about their employees and are quite dismissive when you bring up patient safety issues or unsafe working conditions. As a matter of fact it is in your best interests not to bring up safety issues as it may do more harm than good. Often times I feel like i am jeopardizing my nursing license because of the lack of help and short staffing issues. Nurse to patient ratios are based on numbers only and NEVER acuity. It sounds nice in theory having 4:1 on the floors and 2:1 in the ICUs but things get complicated fast. Since there are no nursing assistants or ancillary help, nurses are responsible for everything. Answering telephones, faxing paperwork, fixing broken printers and computers, heating up patients food, fixing televisions and phone issues. Drawing labs, getting vital signs, taking stat labs to the lab, picking up blood, and then documentation and taking care of the patients gets buried somewhere in there as well. Notice too that Hahnemann only hires new nurses because seasoned nurses in the Philadelphia area know better. If we orient 8 new nurses at least 2 or 3 never make it off orientation or quit soon after. Most nurses do not stay more than 2 years. It's outdated and dirty and sometimes the heat doesn't work in the winter and the air is off in the summer.

review_title: Great learning opportunities but they do not care about working conditions of the nurses
pros: The people at Hahnemann are great and work together well
cons: the administration is difficult to deal with and do not listen to concerns of the employees dealing with direct patient care

review_title: Good job if you’re a good worker

review_title: Although stressful, working at Hahnemann teaches new RNs many aspects of nursing care, and will hire new nurses

cons: compensation, rotating between day and night shifts frequently, work every 3rd weekend, stressful work environment

cons: Feel really unvalued by both nursing and business administration, poor market pay and terrible benefits

pros: Teamwork was the only pro.
cons: I worked in various areas of the hospital before becoming an RN. All areas suffered from poor working conditions, massive turn over of staff, old or shoddy equipment, and non caring management. Very frustrating.

pros: Working with nursing staff was great and challenging. Beautiful experience

pros: Room for growth....high number of patients so theres always work depending on your title and unit
cons: Hours are constanconstantly being cut. Benefits are always changing. There union for support staff but none for MAs. Basically if you're not a RN they pay you no mind.

pros: A great place to build a foundation for new nurses as they will become experts at prioritizing the total care of their patients.

pros: great pay, room for moving up as a tech, great benefits

pros: Great working environment, wonderful people.  Excellent tuition reimbursement.  They encourage you to grow as a professional, whether by attributing certifications of going back to school.
cons: Health insurance plan is just "okay", but not the worst.

pros: A good opportunity to be of help to others in need and gain a positive experience.
cons: When it comes to religious views on vaccines, you either take it or loose your job. What happened to freedom of choice?

pros: top notch nurses and docs, interesting cases and vibrant atmosphere.

pros: Atmosphere of sharing knowledge, caring about the good of the hospital.

pros: A paycheck, some of the people, a lot of bitter angry people working here. Nurses protest every month, the lab is in poor condition.
